shortSummary: Wind through Iceland's East Fjords with their dramatic coastal roads, picturesque fishing villages, and hidden waterfalls, experiencing a more authentic side of Iceland away from the crowds.

Today's adventures include a moderate hike to the stunning Br√∫nav√≠k Beach with its otherworldly landscapes, exploration of a remote mountain road, and up-close encounters with puffins at one of Iceland's best viewing sites. details: 5-mile (8km) round-trip hike with 1,300 feet of elevation gain
Moderate difficulty with some steep sections and uneven terrain
Takes approximately 2.5 hours each way (5 hours total)
Pack lunch to enjoy on the beach
Trail is well-marked but bring a map as cell service is limited
Weather can change quickly - bring layers and rain gear

schedule.description: Experience this remote mountain road in East Iceland leading through picturesque landscapes. The road is suitable for your 4WD Suzuki Vitara and offers stunning mountain and fjord views along the way.
details: Remote F-road with picturesque surroundings and mountain views
No river crossings, primarily rough gravel and steep sections
Route passes through uninhabited wilderness areas
Drive slowly and cautiously, especially on narrow and steep portions
quickStops: Various scenic pullouts for photos of the dramatic landscapes

schedule.description: This relaxed 3-mile loop trail takes you through massive boulders and past turquoise pools in a stunning valley setting. The name translates to 'The Giant Boulders' which perfectly describes this unique landscape.
details: 3-mile loop trail through boulder field and meadows
Several small, brilliantly blue glacier water pools
Relatively easy terrain with some uneven surfaces
Allow 2-3 hours for a leisurely pace with photo stops

schedule.title: Hafnarh√≥lmi Puffin Colony
schedule.description: Visit one of Iceland's best and most accessible puffin viewing areas, with wooden walkways and viewing platforms that bring you remarkably close to these charming birds. July is peak season for puffin watching.
details: Home to thousands of Atlantic puffins (May to mid-August)
Wooden walkways and viewing platforms for safe, close observation
Also home to kittiwakes, fulmars and other seabirds
Mid-evening is often less crowded but still good for photography
Bring binoculars if you have them, though birds are visible without them
